body: +1 to merge
It would be nice to either document behavior, or handle the case where minGram > maxGram (if passed by user mistakenly, for example).

Since patch has applied.

thanks @amensiko great initial start. Couple things jump out:
1. remove all DS_Store files
2. we need to change the package names for the OpenNLP stuff to be o.a.opennlp and remove the edu.usc.ir stuff

I can help with this. @kottmann can I get commit access to Apache OpenNLP so I can help out?
Good work removing the DS_Store. The next step would be to take out the edu.usc.ir stuff, and simply add a pom dependency to the SentimentAnalysiParser USC Central repo jar.

Thanks for the nice work!

I also have a few comments:
- There should be an interface for the Sentiment Analysis Parser e.g. similar to TokenNameFinder or POSTagger. We need this so it is possible to have other implementations of it as well in the future.
- OpenNLP has a command line interface, it would be nice if you could integrate into it.
- SentimentSample should have a toString method, and it should print the sample in the default format (so it can be read in again for training)
- We need evaluation support to know how well it performs (otherwise it can't be improved).
- It would be nice to have tests, especially one which trains and evaluates the performance
- All files in the pull request should have AL headers if possible (e.g. all Java source files)
- In OpenNLP all source files end with a new line

At some point we have to address all of the above, I think it makes sense to get the code quickly into OpenNLP Tools and then continue working on it over there.

I suggest you now do all the changes which can be done quickly and for the ones which take more time you create issues in jira.
Great work @amensiko and great comments @kottmann +1
Great work @amensiko I'll take a look here. Can you see my latest comments too.
SLF4J would make much more sense.
Yes @chrismattmann ! Just fixed it.
Thanks, @autayeu. I changed it from log4j to slf4j.

I took a quick look. Let me think a bit out loud.

OpenNLP is a lib and a toolset (command line tools).

**Lib**: So ideally we'd need to give dev users of the lib enough flexibility to choose a logging lib of their choice. SLF4J is a facade and if properly used, SLF4J should do that. That also means that dependencies beyond slf4j-api, that is, to any particular logging implementation is a drag (log4j-slf4j-impl, log4j-api, log4j-core). What if I'm with logback? Therefore probably slf4j-api should be the only extra dependency for OpenNLP lib.

The usage model here is then as follows: use OpenNLP from your particular project with your particular logging lib and keep your-log-lib dependencies and config files in your project.

**Toolset**: OpenNLP is also a toolset. And here it would be best not to bother end-users with need to configure extra logging, but provide some sensible defaults, probably just emulating current behavior. Therefore, some logging backend should be provided and configured to work out-of-the-box. With optional how-to. I'd go for logback as default backend, and for configuration I'd emulate current behavior in the default log (e.g. no date, class, thread - just the message).

**Logging particulars and code patterns.**
Going from

``` java
System.err.println("Skipping corrupt line: "+line);
```

to

``` java
LOGGER.warn("Skipping corrupt line: "+line);
```

can be improved. A better pattern would be

``` java
LOGGER.warn("Skipping corrupt line: {}", line);
```

This will hopefully lead to fewer string allocations and reduced logging performance penalty. Same note applies everywhere in this pull, especially in places where message is being preconstructed:

``` java
String msg = "Could not instantiate...
LOGGER.error(msg...
```

Those would better be refactored.

**`Log and throw` patterns should be avoided**. But that might lead to changing current behavior, so needs a deeper look. But it would be a good refactoring anyway.

**Logging level should be refactored from messages**:

``` java
LOGGER.warn("Error: ...
```

**This refactoring is a good opportunity to reconsider logging levels**.

``` java
LOGGER.trace("Building ngram dictionary ... ");
```

That was a progress-message, so maybe info rather than trace.

It is also a good time to **reconsider manual formatting in logs**:

``` java
LOGGER.info("Indexing events using cutoff of " + cutoff + "\n");
...
LOGGER.info("\tComputing event counts...  ");
```

\n and \t are not very welcome in logs.

It is also a good time to **reconsider "debug" printing interface**. Going from 

``` java
        if (debugOn) {
            System.out.print(derivationStage + " " + derivationRank + " "+tp.getProb());
            tp.show();
            System.out.println();
        }
```

to 

``` java
        if (LOGGER.isDebugEnabled()) {
            System.out.print(derivationStage + " " + derivationRank + " "+tp.getProb());
            tp.show();
            System.out.println();
        }
```

still leaves some `System.out.print`.

It would also be good to **involve the team and discuss this with others**.

I tried to standardize some of the logging as I mentioned in the JIRA issue. Things like "Building ngram..." seemed to me to be trace actions if it was just saying what it was doing. I recognize that there could be different viewpoints and that's fine. The log4j dependencies are only included as test dependencies. Main methods in tools still have their system outs. 

My intention of this pull request was to start a discussion. I apologize if you don't think this was the best way to start the discussion. Feel free to decline it.

Using JUL or Apache Commons Logging API instead of having a dependency of the OpenNLP library on a full-fledged logging system would in my opinion (as an integrator) be preferrable. So +1 to what @autayeu  said.

@jzonthemtn A pull is a better way to start discussion. It shows more action and commitment compared to emails. Things I noted above are things I would do if I would be doing logging (=personal opinion). To make it less personal, I've added arguments, explanations and better alternatives. Anyway, team consensus might be more important than individual opinion, which is I included the need for team discussion.

@reckart Good to hear, thank you. JUL is the only logger without extra dependency, but the interface is so-so (e.g. SLF4J is less of a performance impact). I'd stay away from Commons Logging as it causes more problems than it solves (dependency, maintenance, performance).
@reckart Typical way for integrators with SLF4J is to use bridges. SLF4J has them for many logging backends. That allows you to continue using your logging backend from your existing project.

@autayeu yes, I know. But SLF4J has been causing me more problems in the past than JUL or ACL API (not ACL impl!). I guess that is because typically people that use SFL4J have dependency on more than just the API and then I end up with conflicting versions of SLF4J in the dependency and with stupid warnings during startup. Whereas if I am in a setup where I want to use SLF4J (or Log4J or whatnot), I can easily install an adapter for ACL - and half-easily for JUL. While the ACL API is arguably dated, I had the least problems with it so far.
@reckart That's interesting. Thank you.
thanks @amensiko !
It was merged.

- The file with the conflict above should be removed (PR 11 is already merged)
- The reason it wasn't merged is that the tests are not running anymore, maven says the following:

```
[INFO] 
[INFO] --- maven-surefire-plugin:2.19.1:test (default-test) @ opennlp-tools ---
[INFO] Tests are skipped.
[INFO] 
```

I am not sure why that is exactly. Do you know why?

The commit message should contain the jira number e.g. See issue OPENNLP-900. I can add this during merging. Otherwise you can edit the message via "git commit --amend" and then you would use "git push --force" to update this PR.

- I get a compilation error in this branch:
[INFO] -------------------------------------------------------------

[INFO] 1 error

- There are also still many changes with tab indents instead of two spaces.

I made the changes to the method signatures as requested by smathi, but we missed the change to the signature to OnePassRealValueEventStream.  Even though the method signatures are similar, they are different so index was not overridden.  I changed the signature and added the "@Override". If the annotation was on the method before, Eclipse would have caught that the signature needed to be changed.
sorry about that... hit the wrong button.

Looks like the current config is not excluding the stemmers, this seems to work:
```<excludes>**/stemmer/**/*</excludes>```
Nitpick: Add the Jira# in title

@smarthi isn't it nicer if the jira is not in the title, but in the body? The title should have only something like 50 chars, if I add the jira it can be very hard to still stick somehow to that limit. I believe GH is splitting the first line after 68 chars or so. A good title has to be shorter than that, or it doesn't look nice in the short commit log.

I think we can merge this now. Any opinions? 

A few lambdas are not correct according to checkstyle, but they look fine to me.

Thanks a lot for helping with this! And thanks for your patience with our bigger code changes in between.
@kottmann I'm having trouble merging it. Maybe you have some advice?

Shouldn't be difficult. As far as I can see you only get conflicts in CLI.java and TokenNameFinderTrainerTool.java. The later one shouldn't be changed by you anyway (so this one I would remove from your commit).

I would do it like this:
1. Get the upstream master branch
2. Remove changes to TokenNameFinderTrainerTool.java from your commits or make a new commit to undo the changes you did, e.g.:
git checkout 4fb05c72a498b291c57f0dfe5664fb719e6d7202  opennlp-tools/src/main/java/opennlp/tools/cmdline/namefind/TokenNameFinderTrainerTool.java
and then commit that version.

3. Rebase your branch onto master
4. send us a new PR against master (I think you can't update this one)
Probably we should also implement hashCode, what do you think?
Also need to add hashCode() method to each of the models.

Are you using Intellij?
No, I use eclipse.  I have installed the OpenNLP-Eclipse-formatter.xml.  A lot of the tab/2 space errors are automatically fixed.  I am just not used to using so many spaces.

We are kind of half-eclipse and half-intellij, I use both. Point out if there are errors in the eclipse formatter template. There is also now standardized import order. smarthi is working on this currently. You should import the OpenNLP-importorder file when it gets published.
Did I break Travis?  It appears to be stuck.
No, the ASF only has 30 containers or so to build all projects. The job is waiting to be started.

neh,, all Apache projects use Travis and hence the jobs are queued up
waiting to be picked up

The existing code is creating the TrainingParameters and then hands over a Map of the settings, and the ml code is then again creating the TrainingParameters. I suggest we also update TrainerFactory to accept the TrainerParameter object as well.

For example have a look at the NameFinderME.train method.

Commit message should be in imperative:
OPENNLP-927: Remove PluggableParameter 

and maybe say slightly more e.g:
OPENNLP-927: Replace PluggableParameter with TrainingParameters
